data.title: Medals & Awards
data.text:
Nominations for the 2024 Chalmers Medal are now open.

The Chalmers Medal is awarded to researchers in tropical medicine or global health who obtained their last relevant qualification between 15 and 20 years ago, who demonstrate evidence of mentoring and professional development of junior investigators.

Nominations for the Emerging Leaders Award will next open in 2025.

The Emerging Leaders Award recognises significant contributions in leadership and service, including mentoring and other forms of capacity-building, to the fields of tropical medicine and global health.

Nominations for the Donald Mackay Medal are now open.

The Donald Mackay Medal is for outstanding work in tropical medicine and health, especially relating to improvements in the health of rural or urban workers in the tropics. The Medal is joint between RSTMH and the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

Nominations for the 2024 Sir Rickard Christophers Medal are now closed.

The Sir Rickard Christophers Medal is awarded triennially for work in tropical medicine and hygiene in its broadest sense and in particular for practical and field applications.

The RSTMH Student Essay Prize is for students studying global health as a degree or any degree with a component of global health.

Submissions for the photo contest are now closed.

Submit your images to the "Global Challenges in Health: Your stories from around the world" – a photo contest from RSTMH and ECTMIH 2021.

Nominations are now closed.

This joint award with Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine (LSTM) recognises Professor Janet Hemingway’s achievements in delivering and encouraging translational science during her leadership of LSTM.

Nominations for the 2024 Chalmers Medal are now open.

The Chalmers Medal is awarded to researchers in tropical medicine or global health who obtained their last relevant qualification between 15 and 20 years ago, who demonstrate evidence of mentoring and professional development of junior investigators.

The Sir Patrick Manson Medal is awarded triennially. It is the Society's highest mark of distinction, and will be awarded to the living person whose contribution to any branch of tropical medicine or hygiene is considered by the Board of Trustees to merit the honour most.

Nominations next open in 2026

This triennial joint award with the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine recognises outstanding research leading to improvement of health in the tropics.

The Clinical Impact Awards are prestigious awards granted to NHS consultant doctors, dentists and academic GPs via an annual competition and seek to recognise the unique and specialised role they play and the impact of their work on the NHS at a national level.
